array.string: Ensure aerosols are completely empty before recycling
Do not pierce, crush or flatten aerosol cans
Detach any loose or easily removable parts, such as the lid, and dispose of them with the rest of your recycling
Rinse or wipe off any crumbs or food residue from foil trays.
Scrunch kitchen foil, tub and pot lids and wrappers together to form a ball.

dict.string: Check with your District or County Council whether they accept it.

array.string: Place in your general waste bin.
If the service is offered in your area, put in your household garden waste collections.
Otherwise take to the recycling center and recycle with garden waste.
Or add to your home composting bin or use as soil fertiliser
Check with your council to see if they are accepted as part of your household collection.
In most ares you will need to take them to a recycling centre or a collection poitn in a supermarket.
Empty and rinse items.
You can leave labels on.
Pass them on to someone else.
Or donate them to a charity shop.
Or sell them.
Some councils now offer a household collection for the recycling of bubble wrap, but this is still limited.
Alternatively, bubble wrap can be recycled along with plastic film and carrier bags at collection points such as supermarkets.
It's always helpful to keep a stash of buttons, as you never know when you mignt need them.
Alternatively, you can always donate them to a charity shop.
Empty and rinse items.
You can leave labels on.
Tape, polystyrene and plastic inserts need to be removed from cardboard packaging.
Glitter, badges and batteries should also be torn off greeting cards.
Egg boxes and rolls from kitchen towel and toilet rolls can also be home composted.
Leave plastic tops on and straws in, as these will be removed and recycled.
Paper is a valuable recyclable material, but only when it is clean.
Remove any plastic wrapping - this can be recycled with plastic bags at larger supermarkets.
If you scrunch paper and it doesn't spring back, then it can be recycled.
Some local recycling centres will accept CDs and DVDs.
However you could donate them to a Charity Shop.
Or sell them on sites like eBay or Music Magpie.
If you have large amounts to recycle, you could purchase a zero waste box from Terracycle UK.
Check to see if your council offeres clothes and textiles collections.
Otherwise, drop off your unwanted items at recycling points and clothing and textile banks in supermarkets and local car parks.
Clothes can often also be donated to registered charites and re-use organisations.
Many high street retailers such as Primark and M&S now offer clothing donatinon banks in-store.
If the clothes are still in good condition, you could consider reselling on sites such as Depop and Ebay.
Some brands are collected by TerraCycle.
They are then recycled to create new products.
Try taking them to your local charity shop, as many charities accept old and foreign coins to help raise valuable funds.
You can also often donate foreign coins on your return flight from holiday.
Compostable plastics can't go in with your plastic recycling as they can't be recycled in the same way.
They can be either home compostable or industrially compostable.
Industrially compostable plastics need to go into your food or garden compost, but check with your Local Authority.
Home compostable plastics can go on your compost heap at home.

dict.string: Take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre.

array.string: Make sure that you permanently delete all files and remove your personal data to reduce the risk of it being used by someone else.
Companies like Apple also offer recycling and trade-in schemes.
Cooking oil and fat can cause blockages, so do not pour down your sink.
Small amounts of cooking oil, fats and plate scrapings can be added to your food waste recycling service.
Otherwise, put it in a sealed container and place in the general waste bin.
If you have a home compost bin, corks can be put in here.
Some stores recycle corks.
When chopped into small pieces, cork can also be used as mulch on plants.
Even those with paper stems should be palced in the waste bin.
Never flush them down the toilet, as they can block systems and pollute the environment.
Plastic stemmed cotton buds were due to be banned in England from April 2020.
Should be placed in your rubbish bin.
Do not try to flush away, as it expands when placed in water and can cause blockages.
Place in your rubbish bin.
Or recycle via TerraCycle's Crisp Packet Recycling Scheme.
Donate items that are still in a good, usable condition to charities or charity shops.
Baubels are not recyclable - theys hould be disposed off in general waste. If made from glass, make sure to wrap up.
Tinsel should be disposed off in your general waste.
Natural materials on wreaths can be composted as long as they are not covered with excessive glitter.
Artificial decorations such as ribbons and plastic flowers must go in the general waste.
If made from wood, then it can be palced in a garden waste collection to be composted.
If made from plastic, it is unlikely to be recycled as it will fall out during the de-contamination process.
The best thing to do is to avoid using if at all possible.
These can be wiped clean and re-used.
However the best practice is avoid using them if possible.
Can be included in your food waste collection scheme in your area if you have one.
They can also be included in your home composting bin.
Some local authorities collect small electrical items as part of their kerbside collection.
Otherwise you can recycle these at selected retailers and at Household Waste Recycling Centres.
If it still works, consider donating or selling this on to someone else.
Can be recycled at most larger household waste recycling centres and some stores.
Can be recycled at your nearest recycling bank.
Make sure it is stored in a sealed container.
Don't mix it with any other substance, as this makes it difficult to recycle.
Paper is a valuable recyclabel material, but only when it is clean.
Remove any plastic wrapping or inserts.
If you scrunch paper and it doesn't spring back, then it can be recycled.
Rinse or wipe of any crumbs or food residue.
Scrunch up to form a ball.
These should be placed in your rubbish bina s they are not usually accepted in your recycling collections from home.
However, some brands are collected by a company called TerraCycle, who recycle them to create new products.
If your local authority has given you a kitchen caddy to collect food waste, you can usually ercycle any cooked or raw food scraps.
Make sure that you remove all packaging, especially plastic.
Alternatively, you could make compost at home.
However you cannot compost cooked food, fish, meat or dairy products.
Some household waste recycling centres accept toys and game, but it is best to check first.
These are not collected as part of household collections, so should not be put in your home recycling.
If they are still in good condition, you could try to sell or donate them.
If they are beyond repair, it may still be possible to recycle someof the parts if you dismantle them.
Some local authorites provide a special bin for your garden waste, and collect it as part of their household collection scheme.
If you don't have this service, or your bin is full, you can recycle garden waste at you rnearest Household Waste Recycling Centre.
If you are provided the service, make sure you follow any special instructions for what can and can't be included.
Do not include any other items, unless your council tells you that it is ok.
If taking garden waste to your local recycling centre, use a strong, durable bag (not a black bin liner), and try not to overfill it.
Once emptied, you can then take this bag back home with you and re use it.
Gas bottles can be refilled for further use, and should be returned to the supplier.
Do not place in your waste bin, as they may explode if they are crushed.
Some local authorities accept gas bottles at household waste reycling centres, but check where they should be left so that they can be stored safely.
Some parts of the packaging is recyclable, but it will need to be separated and sorted.
Remove plastic windows from cardboard boxes before recycling - the plastic should be put in the rubbish bin.
Flatten cardboard for ease of transport, or to fit more into you rrecycling bin.
Plastic blisters marked PET or PETE can be recycled by most local authorities, but check first.
Wire tires are not generally recyclable, but can be re-used around the home.
Remove rope or ribbon handles - these can be re-used or should be placed in the rubbish bin.
Empty and rinse.
Put lids and caps back on.
Corks should be removed.
Most cards are paper based and can be recycled along with their envelopes.
Any embellishments, such as ribbons glitter, cannot be recycled s oshould be removed first.
All used inhalers should be returned to a pharmacy to be disposed of safely.
These are increasingly being collected at local recycling centres.
But are not generally collected from kerbside.
However, you may be able to donate them to charity.
There are specialist services, charities and other organisations who will take your unwanted or borken jewellery.
If in good quality, you may be able to sell it.
If donating, place in a separate plastc bag to keep them together.
Paper is a valuable recyclable material, but only when it is clean.
Remove any plastic wrapping.
If you scurnch paper and it doesn't spring back, then it can be recycled.
Can be recyceld in the mixed metals recycling facility at most local recycling centres.
The cardboard inner tube is widely collected as part of household recycling schemes.
Used sheets of kitchen roll should be placed in your rubbish bin, unless your council tells you otherwise.
Some will allow you to put a small amout of kitchen towel in the food waste bin - but check first.
Should be placed in your rubbish bins.
Paper is a valuable recyclable material, but only when it is clean.
Remove any plastic wrapping - this can be recycled with plastic bags at larger supermarkets.
You can recycle engine oil at your nearest recycling bank.
Most packaging is recyclable, but it will need to be separated and sorted.
Before recycling, remove any food or drink residue by rinsining it.
Squash items if possible, to make more space in your bin.
Food and drinks cans and plastic bottles are widely ercycled.
Check locally for plastic pots, tubs and trays.
Plastic films and carrier bags are not usually collected, but can be recycled at carrier bag collection points.
Your local household waste recycling centre may have a donation point for paint - it is re-used rather than recycled.
Alternatively, donate your paint to a local Community Repaint scheme.
Make sure you harden your paint before disposable.
Solvent based paint, paint thinner and white spirit should be disposed of as hazardous waste.
Empty metal paint cans are accepted at most household waste recycling centres.
These must be empty or dry.
Currently, plastic paint cans are not widely accepted.
Paper is a valuable recyclable material, but only when it is clean.
Remove any plastic wrapping.
If you scrunch paper and it doesn't spring back, then it can be recycled.
Not normally accpeted in household recycling collection schemes, especially when used.
High street coffee store chains often accept returns of these for recycling.
These often provide discounts when you do return them.
Make sure that you check with your local council that they accept it.
Pizza boxes are recyclable, even when stained or greasy as long as they are empty.
However, it may be worth check this with your local authority.
Find your local carrier bag collection point.
These can be found at most major supermarkets, including Tesco, Asda, Morrisons, Sainsbury's, The Co-op and Waitrose.
Empty and rinse.
Leave on labels.
Replace lids and tops.
Squash bottles to save space.
Most local authorities collect pots, tubs and trays in their kerbside collection.
If they do, then you should be able to put non-black plastic plant pots in your normal home recycling collection.
Tubes containing DIY products like mastic cannot be recycled.
Pump-action toothpaste tubes are easy to recycle.
Plastic items that are less thatn 40x40mm are unlikely to be recycled.
Rinse food packaging.
Labels and lids can all be left on, but plastic film must be removed.
Used stamps can be recycled with paper if they are still attached to envelopes.
Alternatively, you can collect stamps for charities.
If in good condition, these can be donated to some charity shops.
You could also sell them online.
If not suitable for re-use or re-sale, they will need to be disposed of in the bin.
Carboard sleeves should be removed and recycled.
If in good condition, these could be donated to charity.
Otherwise can be recycled at your local Household Waste Recycling Centre.
Empty and rinse bottles.
Leave on labels.
Replace lids and tops.
Squash bottles to save space.
You can take your old or unwanted shoes and boots to most recycling centres, put them in a bring bank, or donate to a charity shop.
Where possible, these can be sold for re-use.
To help prevent greenhouse gas emissions from tea bags rotting in landfill, place your tea bags in a food or garden waste collection scheme if you have one.
Floor and wall tiles are not collected as part of your councils household recycling scheme.
However, you can usually take them to your local Household Waste Recycling Centre.
Tyres can be taken to household waste recycling centres.
However, there may be a limit to how many you can take, and you may also be charged.
When you need new tyres on your car, the garage where you have them fitted may dipose of your old ones for you.
Water filters cannot be recycled as part of a collection scheme or at a recycling centre.
Howver, BRITA branded filters can be recycled at most Argos, Robert Dyas and Homebase stores, or using TerraCycle.
Wipes are not recyclable, but are also not flushable.
They should always be placed in your rubbish bin.
